entity that can be referenced and used for learning, education and training
Note 1 to entry: learning resource: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-36:2008].
Note 2 to entry: 36.05.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-36 * 2008 * * * ]
2122970
learning strategy
<artificial intelligence> plan for the use of learning techniques prior to their application
Note 1 to entry: learning strategy: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-31:1997].
Note 2 to entry: 31.01.05 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-31 * 1997 * * * ]
2178066
learning strategy
<learning, education and training> set of methods and techniques usually used by a learner to learn
Note 1 to entry: It includes elements generally known to determine a profile, such as how a student prefers to receive, process and use information.
Note 2 to entry: learning strategy: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-36:2008].
Note 3 to entry: 36.06.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-36 * 2008 * * * ]
2178058
learning technology system
information technology system used in the delivery and management of learning
Note 1 to entry: learning technology system; LTS: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-36:2008].
Note 2 to entry: 36.03.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-36 * 2008 * * * ]
2123020
learning while doing
reinforcement learning that relies not on waiting for a solution path to be found before assigning blame, but on assigning credit and blame while the search for the solution is still on
Note 1 to entry: Learning while doing includes techniques for noting loops and unnecessarily long paths, dead-ends, and failures, to progress toward a goal.
Note 2 to entry: learning while doing: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-31:1997].
Note 3 to entry: 31.03.25 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-31 * 1997 * * * ]
2123019
learning-apprentice strategy
credit/blame assignment that involves observing an expert and using his or her actions to distinguish desirable moves from undesirable ones so as to avoid excessive search, and providing immediate feedback
Note 1 to entry: The learning-apprentice strategy is frequently applied in the semi-automated construction of expert systems.
Note 2 to entry: learning-apprentice strategy: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-31:1997].
Note 3 to entry: 31.03.24 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-31 * 1997 * * * ]
2121065
least significant bit
<representation of data> in positional notation, bit position having the smallest weight used
Note 1 to entry: least significant bit; LSB: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 2 to entry: 05.04.08 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2121064
least significant digit
in positional notation, digit place having the smallest weight used
Note 1 to entry: least significant digit; LSD: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 2 to entry: 05.04.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2126214
left-aligned
left-adjusted
flush left
left-justified
pertaining to text that is aligned to the left margin, but need not be aligned to the right margin
Note 1 to entry: left-aligned; left-adjusted; flush left; left-justified: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-23:1994].

2123817
left-hand side
premise part

2120730
linear prediction coding
prediction coding in which the predicted signal samples are linear combinations of the previous samples
Note 1 to entry: The coefficients of the linear combinations are generally obtained by minimizing the mean square error between the input signal and the signal predicted from prior data.

2121929
linkage editor
linker
program, that, when processing one or more independently translated object modules or load modules, resolves cross-references among these modules, provides links between or among them, establishes relocatable elements, and, if necessary, adjusts addresses, thus creating new load modules

technique of magnetic recording in which magnetic polarities representing data are aligned along the length of the recording track

Note 2 to entry: 12.03.09 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2121828
loop
sequence of statements or of instructions that may be executed iteratively while a certain condition prevails
Note 1 to entry: In some implementations, no test is made to discover whether the condition prevails until the loop has been executed once.
Note 2 to entry: loop: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].
Note 3 to entry: 07.03.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]

2123027
maintainability
ability of a functional unit, under given conditions of use, to be retained in, or restored to, a state in which it can perform a required function when maintenance is performed under given conditions and using stated procedures and resources
Note 1 to entry: The term used in IEV 191-02-07 is "maintainability performance" and the definition is the same.
Note 2 to entry: maintainability: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].
Note 3 to entry: 14.01.06 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-14 * 1997 * * * ]
2123026
maintenance
set of activities intended to keep a functional unit in, or to restore it to, a state in which it can perform a required function
Note 1 to entry: Maintenance includes activities such as monitoring, tests, measurements, replacements, adjustments, repairs, and in some cases administrative actions.
Note 2 to entry: See also IEV 191-07-01 where a slightly different wording is used.
Note 3 to entry: maintenance: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].
Note 4 to entry: 14.01.05 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-14 * 1997 * * * ]
2126355
maintenance hook
trapdoor in software that allows easy maintenance and development of additional features and that may allow entry into the program at unusual points or without the usual checks

2124145
majority operation
threshold operation in which each of the operands may take only the values 0 and 1, and that takes the value 1 if and only if the number of operands having the value 1 is greater than the number of operands that have the value zero
Note 1 to entry: majority operation: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 2 to entry: 02.10.11 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2126363

program implemented in hardware, firmware, or software, and whose purpose is to perform some unauthorized or harmful action

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-8 * 1998 * * * ]
2121127
management domain
<electronic mail> set of messaging systems, at least one of which contains a message transfer agent, that is managed by a single organization
Note 1 to entry: A management domain may correspond to a geographical area.
Note 2 to entry: The managing organization is particularly responsible for the administration of the addressing scheme in this set of messaging systems.
Note 3 to entry: management domain; MD: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-32:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 32.02.12 (2382)

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-32 * 1999 * * * ]
2121419
management information system
information processing system that supports decision-making by the management of an organization

Note 2 to entry: 17.01.05 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-17 * 1999 * * * ]
2124389
Manchester encoding
binary phase encoding in which the time interval assigned to each bit is divided in half by a transition whose direction determines the value of the bit
Note 1 to entry: The transition may occur between two states of a physical variable such as voltage, magnetic polarity, or light intensity.
Note 2 to entry: If the physical variable is electrical, this type of encoding is polarity-dependent and is free of a DC component.
Note 3 to entry: Manchester encoding: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995].
Note 4 to entry: 09.05.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-9 * 1995 * * * ]
2122964
manipulating industrial robot
automatically controlled, reprogrammable, multipurpose, manipulative machine with several degrees of freedom, which may be either fixed in place or mobile for use in industrial automation applications
Note 1 to entry: The terms "fixed robot" and "mobile robot" are sometimes used to refer to manipulating industrial robots.
Note 2 to entry: manipulating industrial robot: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-24:1995].
Note 3 to entry: 24.04.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-24 * 1995 * * * ]
2126392
manipulation detection
modification detection
procedure that is used to detect whether data have been modified, either accidentally or intentionally
Note 1 to entry: manipulation detection; modification detection: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-8:1998].
Note 2 to entry: 08.06.23 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-8 * 1998 * * * ]
2126393
manipulation detection code
modification detection code
bit string that is a function of data to which it is attached to allow manipulation detection
Note 1 to entry: The resulting message (data plus MDC) may then be encrypted in order to achieve secrecy or data authentication.
Note 2 to entry: The function used to generate the MDC must be public.
Note 3 to entry: manipulation detection code; modification detection code; MDC: terms, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-8:1998].
Note 4 to entry: 08.06.24 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-8 * 1998 * * * ]
2121081
mantissa
<floating-point representation> numeral that is multiplied by the exponentiated floating-point base to determine the real number represented
Note 1 to entry: Example: See the example in entry floating-point representation (05.05.02).
Note 2 to entry: mantissa: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 05.05.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2124053
mantissa
<arithmetic and logic operations> non-negative fractional part of the representation of a logarithm
Note 1 to entry: mantissa: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 2 to entry: 02.02.09 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2124456
manual answering
answering in which a call is established only if the called user indicates a readiness to receive the call by means of a manual operation
Note 1 to entry: manual answering: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995].

2124042
mathematical induction
method of proving a statement concerning terms based on natural numbers not less than N by showing that the statement is valid for the term based on N and that, if it is valid for an arbitrary value of n that is greater than N, it is also valid for the term based on (n + 1)
Note 1 to entry: mathematical induction: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 2 to entry: 02.01.02 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-13 * 1996 * * * ]
2122558
maximum allowable common mode overvoltage
highest value of the common mode voltage that can be applied to an input subsystem without causing circuit damage, but with the possibility of a temporary loss of function
Note 1 to entry: If it is clear from the context, this term may be shortened to "maximum allowable overvoltage".
Note 2 to entry: The following relationship exists: the maximum common mode voltage is lower than the maximum operating common mode voltage which is lower than the "maximum allowable common mode overvoltage".
Note 3 to entry: maximum allowable common mode overvoltage: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-21:1985].
Note 4 to entry: 21.05.08 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-21 * 1985 * * * ]
2122557
maximum allowable normal mode overvoltage
highest value of the normal mode voltage that can be applied to an input subsystem without causing circuit damage, but with the possibility of a temporary loss of function
Note 1 to entry: If it is clear from the context, this term may be shortened to "maximum allowable overvoltage".
Note 2 to entry: The following relationship exists: the maximum normal mode voltage is lower than the maximum operating normal mode voltage which is lower than the "maximum allowable normal mode overvoltage".
Note 3 to entry: maximum allowable normal mode overvoltage: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-21:1985].
Note 4 to entry: 21.05.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-21 * 1985 * * * ]
2122554
maximum common mode voltage
highest value for the common mode voltage at which the subsystem will still operate according to its specifications
Note 1 to entry: The following relationship exists: the "maximum common mode voltage" is lower than the maximum operating common mode voltage which is lower than the maximum allowable common mode overvoltage.
Note 2 to entry: maximum common mode voltage: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-21:1985].
Note 3 to entry: 21.05.04 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-21 * 1985 * * * ]
2122553
maximum normal mode voltage
highest value for the normal mode voltage at which the subsystem will continue to operate according to its specifications
Note 1 to entry: The following relationship exists: the "maximum normal mode voltage" is lower than the maximum operating normal mode voltage which is lower than the maximum allowable normal mode overvoltage.
Note 2 to entry: maximum normal mode voltage: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-21:1985].
Note 3 to entry: 21.05.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-21 * 1985 * * * ]
2122556
maximum operating common mode voltage
highest value for the common mode voltage that can be applied to an input subsystem and at which the subsystem will continue to operate, but at reduced performance
Note 1 to entry: If it is clear from the context, this term may be shortened to "maximum operating voltage".
Note 2 to entry: The following relationship exists: the maximum common mode voltage is lower than the "maximum operating common mode voltage" which is lower than the maximum allowable common mode overvoltage.
Note 3 to entry: maximum operating common mode voltage: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-21:1985].
Note 4 to entry: 21.05.06 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-21 * 1985 * * * ]
2122555
maximum operating normal mode voltage
highest value for the normal mode voltage that can be applied to an input subsystem and at which the subsystem will continue to operate, but at reduced performance
Note 1 to entry: If it is clear from the context, this term may be shortened to "maximum operating voltage".
Note 2 to entry: The following relationship exists: the maximum normal mode voltage is lower than the "maximum operating normal mode voltage" which is lower than the maximum allowable normal mode overvoltage.
Note 3 to entry: maximum operating normal mode voltage: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-21:1985].
Note 4 to entry: 21.05.05 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-21 * 1985 * * * ]
2125574

2123035
mean operating time between failures
mean duration of operation between consecutive failures of a functional unit under given conditions
Note 1 to entry: This definition combines those found in IEV 191-10-04, which refers explicitly to repaired items, and in IEV 191-12-09.
Note 2 to entry: IEV 191-12-09 also uses the abbreviation "MTBF" for this term.
Note 3 to entry: mean operating time between failures: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].
Note 4 to entry: 14.02.02 (2382)

2122539

Note 2 to entry: 21.03.19 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-21 * 1985 * * * ]
2123034
mean time between failures
<reliability, maintainability and availability> mean duration between consecutive failures of a functional unit under given conditions
Note 1 to entry: Mean time between failures can be derived from a theoretical model or from observations.
Note 2 to entry: This definition combines those found in IEV 191-10-03, which refers explicitly to repaired items, and in IEV 191-12-08.
Note 3 to entry: mean time between failures: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].
Note 4 to entry: 14.02.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-14 * 1997 * * * ]
2123060
mean time to recovery
mean time to restoration
for a given functional unit, mean duration required for restoration of operations after a failure
Note 1 to entry: The definition in IEV 191-13-08 defines the same concept differently and also uses the abbreviation "MTTR" for these terms.
Note 2 to entry: mean time to recovery; mean time to restoration: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].
Note 3 to entry: 14.04.11 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-14 * 1997 * * * ]
2123223
mean transinformation content
average transinformation content
mean value of the transinformation content of two events, each in one of two finite sets of mutually exclusive and jointly exhaustive events; in mathematical notation, this measure is T(X,Y) = [...][...] p(x[subscript i],y[subscript j] T(x[subscript i],y[subscript j]) where X = {x[subscript 1] ... x[subscript n]} is the set of events x[subscript i] (i = 1 ... n), Y = {y[subscript 1] ... y[subscript m]} is the set of events y[subscript j] = (1 ... m), T(x[subscript i],y[subscript j]) is the transinformation content of x[subscript i] and y[subscript j], and p(x[subscript i],y[subscript j]), the joint probability that both events occur
Note 1 to entry: The mean transinformation content is symmetric in X and Y. It is also equal to the difference between the entropy of one of the two sets of events and the conditional entropy of this set relative to the other: T(X,Y) = H(X) - H(X|Y) = H(Y) - H(Y|X) = T(Y,X)
Note 2 to entry: The mean transinformation content is a quantitative measure of information transmitted through a channel, when X is a specific set of messages at the message source and Y is a specific set of messages at the message sink. It is equal to the difference between the entropy at the message source and the equivocation, or the difference between the entropy at the message sink and the irrelevance.
Note 3 to entry: mean transinformation content; average transinformation content: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-16:1996].
Note 4 to entry: 16.04.08 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-16 * 1996 * * * ]
2123843
means-ends analysis
means-end analysis
problem solving that, at every step, searches for operations that maximally lower the difference between the existing state and a known goal state
Note 1 to entry: means-ends analysis; means-end analysis: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-28:1995].
Note 2 to entry: 28.03.16 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-28 * 1995 * * * ]

Note 2 to entry: 32.02.10 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-32 * 1999 * * * ]
2121124
message transfer system
functional unit consisting of one or more message transfer agents that provides store-and-forward message transfer between user agents, message stores, and access units
Note 1 to entry: message transfer system; MTS: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-32:1999].
Note 2 to entry: 32.02.09 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-32 * 1999 * * * ]
2121119

part of a message handling system with functional significance

2123815

knowledge about the structure, use, and control of knowledge

2124426

network for connecting local area networks located in the same urban area
Note 1 to entry: A MAN generally operates at a higher speed than the networks interconnected, crosses administrative boundaries, and supports several access methods.

2122044
microinstruction
directive that specifies one or more of the basic operations needed to carry out a machine instruction or another self-contained hardware function, and that denotes the operands belonging to these operations
Note 1 to entry: Microinstructions are the true machine instructions, and microcode is used to create a virtual machine that appears to have a more user-friendly instruction set.
Note 2 to entry: microinstruction: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].
Note 3 to entry: 07.08.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]

2123030
mistake

error
human action or inaction that can produce an unintended result

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-14 * 1997 * * * ]
2121078
mixed base notation
numeration system in which a number is represented as the sum of a series of terms each of which consists of a mantissa and a base, the base of a given term being constant for a given application, but the bases being such that there are not necessarily integral ratios between the bases of all the terms
Note 1 to entry: Example: With bases b[subscript 3], b[subscript 2], and b[subscript 1] and mantissae 6, 5, and 4, the number represented is given by 6b[subscript 3] + 5b[subscript 2] + 4b[subscript 1].
Note 2 to entry: mixed base notation: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 05.04.21 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2122443
mixed mode
mixed type
pertaining to an expression that contains two or more different data types
Note 1 to entry: mixed mode; mixed type: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-15:1999].
Note 2 to entry: 15.05.34 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-15 * 1999 * * * ]
2121069
mixed radix notation
radix notation in which the digit places do not all necessarily have the same radix
Note 1 to entry: Example: The numeration system in which three successive digits represent hours, tens of minutes, and minutes; taking one minute as the unit, the weights of the three digit places are 60, 10, and 1 respectively; the radices of the second and third digit places are 6 and 10 respectively.
Note 2 to entry: A comparable numeration system that used one or more digits to represent days and two digits to represent hours would not satisfy the definition of any radix notation, since the ratio of the weights of the "day" and the "tens of hours" digit places would not be an integer.
Note 3 to entry: mixed radix notation: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 05.04.12 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2123876
model-based expert system
model-based system
expert system that integrates the structure and function of a domain model
Note 1 to entry: Example: The "student models" that can be found in some intelligent tutoring systems, and the templates that are built in some diagnostic systems.
Note 2 to entry: model-based expert system; model-based system: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-28:1995].

2120645

layered network having at least two layers

2120657
multilayered perceptron
feedforward network consisting of a group of source nodes, one or more hidden layers, and one output layer, and using a monotonic activation function
Note 1 to entry: Each artificial neuron in a multilayered perceptron is a single-layer perceptron.
Note 2 to entry: Multilayered perceptrons can implement any Boolean function.
Note 3 to entry: multilayered perceptron: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-34:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 34.02.28 (2382)

2126397
mutual suspicion

2120533
network
arrangement of entities and their interconnections
Note 1 to entry: In network topology or in an abstract arrangement, the interconnected entities are points on a scheme, and the interconnections are lines on the scheme. In a computer network, the interconnected entities are computers or data communication equipment, and the interconnections are data links.
Note 2 to entry: network: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-18:1999].

2120671
neural connection
neural link
synaptic interconnection
synaptic connection
link between two artificial neurons that is defined by the source neuron, the destination neuron, and a connection weight

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-34 * 1999 * * * ]
2120625
neural network
neural net
artificial neural network
network of primitive processing elements connected by weighted links with adjustable weights, in which each element produces a value by applying a nonlinear function to its input values, and transmits it to other elements or presents it as an output value
Note 1 to entry: Whereas some neural networks are intended to simulate the functioning of neurons in the nervous system, most neural networks are used in artificial intelligence as realizations of the connectionist model.
Note 2 to entry: Examples of nonlinear functions are a threshold function, a sigmoid function, and a polynomial function.
Note 3 to entry: This entry is an improved version of the entry 28.01.22 in ISO/IEC 2382-28:1995.
Note 4 to entry: neural network; neural net; NN; artificial neural network; ANN: terms, abbreviations and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-34:1999].
Note 5 to entry: 34.01.06 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-34 * 1999 * * * ]
2123790
neural network
neural net
network of primitive processing elements connected by weighted links with adjustable weights, in which each element produces a value by applying a nonlinear function to its input values, and transmits it to other elements or presents it as an output
Note 1 to entry: Neural networks are modeled on the functioning of neurons in the nervous system.
Note 2 to entry: The nonlinear function is usually a threshold function.
Note 3 to entry: neural network; neural net; NN: terms, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-28:1995].
Note 4 to entry: 28.01.22 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-28 * 1995 * * * ]

2120534
node
in a network, entity that is connected to one or more other entities
Note 1 to entry: In network topology or in an abstract arrangement, the nodes are points on a scheme. In a computer network, the nodes are computers or data communication equipment.
Note 2 to entry: A network may contain end nodes and intermediate nodes.
Note 3 to entry: This definition is more general than the definition 09.07.01 in ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995.

2124082

2122526

2125602
non-return-to-zero (change) recording
non-return-to-reference recording in which the zeros are represented by magnetization to a specified condition and ones by another condition; the magnetization changes only when the value to be represented changes
Note 1 to entry: The two conditions may be saturation and zero magnetization, but are more commonly saturation in opposite senses.
Note 2 to entry: non-return-to-zero (change) recording; NRZ(C): term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].
Note 3 to entry: 12.03.21 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2125603
non-return-to-zero change-on-ones recording
non-return-to-zero (mark) recording
non-return-to-zero recording in which the ones are represented by a change in the condition of magnetization, and the zeros are represented by the absence of a change
Note 1 to entry: This method is called "(mark) recording" because only the one or mark signals are explicitly recorded.
Note 2 to entry: non-return-to-zero change-on-ones recording; NRZ-1; non-return-to-zero (mark) recording; NRZ(M): terms, abbreviations and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].
Note 3 to entry: 12.03.22 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2125604
non-return-to-zero change-on-zeros recording
non-return-to-zero recording in which the zeros are represented by a change in the condition of magnetization, and the ones are represented by the absence of a change
Note 1 to entry: non-return-to-zero change-on-zeros recording; NRZ-0: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].
Note 2 to entry: 12.03.23 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2125597
non-return-to-zero recording
non-return-to-reference recording
magnetic recording of bits such that patterns of magnetization used to represent zeros and ones occupy the whole storage cell, with no part of the cell magnetized to the reference condition
Note 1 to entry: non-return-to-zero recording; NRZ; non-return-to-reference recording: terms, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].

2121164
nondelivery
<electronic mail> transmittal event in which a message transfer agent determines that a message cannot be delivered to its immediate recipients, or a report cannot be delivered to the originator of the corresponding message or probe
Note 1 to entry: In the case of a message, the message transfer agent generates a nondelivery report.
Note 2 to entry: nondelivery: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-32:1999].

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-32 * 1999 * * * ]
2121189
nondelivery notification service
service that enables an originator's user agent to request to be notified if a submitted message was not delivered to a recipient's user agent or to an access unit
Note 1 to entry: The reason the message was not delivered may be included as part of the notification.
Note 2 to entry: In the case of a multirecipient message, this notification can refer to any or all recipients to whom the message could not be delivered.
Note 3 to entry: nondelivery notification service: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-32:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 32.06.08 (2382)

2121085
normalize
make an adjustment to the mantissa and the corresponding adjustment to the exponent in a floating-point representation to bring the mantissa within some prescribed range, the real number represented remaining unchanged
Note 1 to entry: The number zero cannot be normalized.
Note 2 to entry: This definition is an improved version of the definition in ISO/IEC 2382-02.
Note 3 to entry: normalize: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 05.05.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2124123
normalize
standardize
<floating-point representation system> make an adjustment to the fixed-point part and the corresponding adjustment to the exponent in a floating-point representation to ensure that the fixed-point part lies within some prescribed range, the real number represented remaining unchanged
Note 1 to entry: Example: In order to bring the fixed-point part into the range 1 to 9.99 ... the floating-point representation 123.45 x 10² may be normalized to 1.2345 x 10[superscript 4].
Note 2 to entry: normalize; standardize: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 3 to entry: 02.09.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]

originator/recipient address
attribute list that distinguishes one user or distribution list from another and defines the user's point of access to the message handling system or the distribution list's location

2121073
octal system
octal numeration system
fixed radix notation that uses the eight digits 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7, a fixed radix of eight, and the lowest integral weight of 1
Note 1 to entry: Example: In the octal system, the numeral 1750 represents 1 x 8³ + 7 x 8² + 5 x 8¹ + 0 x 8[superscript 0] equivalent to the decimal numeral 1 000.
Note 2 to entry: octal system; octal numeration system: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].

2125990
octree
expression of a three-dimensional object as a tree structure of octants, which are formed by recursively subdividing each nonhomogeneous octant until all octants are homogeneous with respect to a selected characteristic, or until a predetermined cutoff depth is reached
Note 1 to entry: The octree technique compresses the amount of stored data about a three-dimensional object.
Note 2 to entry: octree: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-13:1996].
Note 3 to entry: 13.02.37 (2382)

2122067

Note 2 to entry: 26.01.04 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-26 * 1993 * * * ]
2123067
open systems interconnection reference model
OSI reference model
model that describes the general principles of open systems interconnection and the network architecture resulting from those principles
Note 1 to entry: This model, described in ISO 7498 and CCITT X.200, provides a framework for co-ordinating the development of standards which refer to it.
Note 2 to entry: open systems interconnection reference model; OSI reference model: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-26:1993].
Note 3 to entry: 26.01.05 (2382)

2124135
operation
well-defined action that, when applied to any permissible combination of known entities, produces a new entity
Note 1 to entry: Example: The process of addition in arithmetic; in adding five and three and obtaining eight, the numbers five and three are the operands, the number eight is the result, and the plus sign is the operator indicating that the operation performed is addition.
Note 2 to entry: operation: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 3 to entry: 02.10.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2122061
operation code
opcode
encoded representation of the operation part of a machine instruction
Note 1 to entry: Example: In an assembly language, BNZ might be used to designate the operation "branch if not zero", which might be ultimately represented in machine code as a specific bit pattern.
Note 2 to entry: operation code; opcode: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].

2124473
overhead bit
service bit
ancillary bit used for control purposes
Note 1 to entry: Overhead bits are mainly used when the sending equipment carries out a process, particularly an aperiodic process, to ensure that the receiving equipment carries out the corresponding complementary process. They are normally added at regular intervals to a digital signal at the sending end and removed at the receiving end.
Note 2 to entry: overhead bit; service bit: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995].
Note 3 to entry: 09.06.10 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-9 * 1995 * * * ]

2122179
pack

2124436
packet sequencing

2124435
packet switching
in a data network, process of routing and transferring data by means of addressed packets so that, between two nodes, each transmission channel is allocated dynamically to packets having different addresses
Note 1 to entry: packet switching: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995].

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-9 * 1995 * * * ]

page depth
vertical dimension of the area available for printing or displaying on a screen or page
Note 1 to entry: Page length is usually less than the actual paper size, but it may exceed the usual paper size, for example, to create a foldout diagram.

2121173
personal name
attribute of an O/R address as a unique designation of a person relative to the entity denoted by another attribute, e.g., an organization name

2124401
phase coherent frequency shift keying
phase coherent FSK
frequency shift keying in which the predetermined frequencies are whole multiples of the bit rate and transitions between these frequencies are made at zero crossings of the carrier waveform
Note 1 to entry: phase coherent frequency shift keying; phase coherent FSK: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995].

2125598
phase modulation recording
phase encoding
magnetic recording in which each storage cell is divided into two regions which are magnetized in opposite senses; the sequence of these senses indicates whether the binary digit represented is zero or one
Note 1 to entry: phase modulation recording; phase encoding: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].
Note 2 to entry: 12.03.17 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2124402
phase shift keying
<data communication> modulation in which a modulating digital signal varies the phase of the output signal among a fixed number of predetermined values
Note 1 to entry: phase shift keying; PSK: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995].
Note 2 to entry: 09.05.16 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-9 * 1995 * * * ]
2124400
phase-continuous frequency shift keying
phase-continuous FSK
frequency shift keying in which the transition between the predetermined frequencies is accomplished by a change of frequency, in such a way that there is no phase shift at the transition
Note 1 to entry: Phase-continuous frequency shift keying may be contrasted with the discontinuous replacement of one frequency by another, such as might be accomplished by a switch.
Note 2 to entry: phase-continuous frequency shift keying; phase-continuous FSK: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995].
Note 3 to entry: 09.05.14 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-9 * 1995 * * * ]

2123858

Note 1 to entry: Planning is performed with a view toward enhancing search efficiency and solving goal conflicts.

sequence of bits recorded at the end of each block on a magnetic medium, for the purpose of synchronization when reading backward

2124122
postfix notation
suffix notation
reverse Polish notation
method of forming mathematical expressions in which each operator is preceded by its operands and indicates the operation to be performed on the operands or the intermediate results that precede it
Note 1 to entry: Example: A added to B and the sum multiplied by C is represented by the expression AB + C x.
Note 2 to entry: Example: P AND the result of Q AND R is represented by the expression PQR&&.
Note 3 to entry: postfix notation; suffix notation; reverse Polish notation: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 4 to entry: 02.08.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]

measure of the ability to distinguish between nearly equal values
Note 1 to entry: Example: Four-place numerals are less precise than six-place numerals; nevertheless a properly computed four-place numeral may be more accurate than an improperly computed six-place numeral.
Note 2 to entry: precision: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].

built-in
intrinsic
pertaining to a language construct that is declared by the definition of the programming language

identifier that is defined as part of a programming language

2124121
prefix notation
Polish notation
parenthesis-free notation
Lukasiewicz notation
method of forming mathematical expressions in which each operator precedes its operands and indicates the operation to be performed on the operands or the intermediate results that follow it
Note 1 to entry: Example: A added to B and the sum multiplied by C is represented by the expression x + ABC.
Note 2 to entry: Example: P AND the result of Q AND R is represented by the expression &P&QR.

2121838
pretest loop
loop control that performs a test before entry into the loop body
Note 1 to entry: Example: A "for" loop in Ada.
Note 2 to entry: Usually, a pretest loop is preferred, because a posttest loop permits one execution of the loop before the test is first performed.
Note 3 to entry: pretest loop: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].

2124504
primary station
in high-level data link control, part of the data station that supports the primary control functions of the data link, generates commands to be transmitted, and interprets received responses

2123098
primitive
service primitive
<open systems interconnection> abstract description of an interaction between a service user and a service provider
Note 1 to entry: A service user is usually an entity. A service provider at a given layer usually comprises entities of that layer and a lower layer service (except at the physical layer). Therefore, a primitive is also an abstract description of an interaction between two adjacent entities.
Note 2 to entry: primitive; service primitive: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-26:1993].

2122398
private type
within a program, data type whose structure, set of values, and operations are defined but whose availability is restricted to privileged parts of that program
Note 1 to entry: Example: In Ada, only assignment, equality, and inequality are available to users, except for any operations explicitly made accessible.

2121138
probe
<electronic mail> information object that is conveyed by means of message transfer and that is used to determine if the messages can be delivered
Note 1 to entry: The attributes contained in the envelope of the probe describe a class of messages the deliverability of which is to be determined.
Note 2 to entry: The probe may not be expanded by distribution lists.
Note 3 to entry: probe: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-32:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 32.03.09 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-32 * 1999 * * * ]
2122681
problem definition
problem description
statement of a problem, which may include a description of the data, the method, the procedures, and algorithms used to solve it
Note 1 to entry: problem definition; problem description: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-20:1990].
Note 2 to entry: 20.02.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-20 * 1990 * * * ]
2123842
problem reduction
problem solving in which operations are used to decompose a single problem into several subproblems which are usually easier to solve than the original problem
Note 1 to entry: problem reduction: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-28:1995].
Note 2 to entry: 28.03.15 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-28 * 1995 * * * ]
2123780
problem solving
determination of a sequence of operations or actions that may lead to a desired goal
Note 1 to entry: Frequently, problem solving is a process in which one starts from an initial state and proceeds to search through a problem space in order to find the desired goal. Successful problem solving depends upon knowing the initial state, what an acceptable outcome would be, given a desired goal, and the elements or operations that define the problem space.
Note 2 to entry: problem solving: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-28:1995].
Note 3 to entry: 28.01.12 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-28 * 1995 * * * ]
2123839
problem space
conceptual or formal area defined by all of the possible states that can be used in the analysis of interactions between elements and operations that are considered when solving a specific problem
Note 1 to entry: problem space: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-28:1995].
Note 2 to entry: 28.03.12 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-28 * 1995 * * * ]
2121767
problem-oriented language
application-oriented language
programming language that reflects the concepts of a particular application area
Note 1 to entry: Examples: SQL for database applications, COBOL for business applications.
Note 2 to entry: problem-oriented language; application-oriented language: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].
Note 3 to entry: 07.01.15 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]

2121770
procedural language
procedure-oriented language
programming language that provides the means to state what is to be achieved by the actions of a data processing system by giving specific statements or instructions to be executed in a specific sequence
Note 1 to entry: Examples: Ada, BASIC, COBOL, Fortran, and Pascal.
Note 2 to entry: procedural language; procedure-oriented language: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]
2122456
procedure
subroutine
subprogram that does not return a data value, except as part of the parameter mechanism
Note 1 to entry: In COBOL, a procedure is a paragraph, or a group of logically successive paragraphs, or a section (consisting of zero or more paragraphs) within the procedure division.
Note 2 to entry: In some programming languages (i.e., C and C++), the procedure language construct is not differentiated from the function language construct except that returned data values may be void or not used.
Note 3 to entry: procedure; subroutine: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-15:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 15.06.11 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-15 * 1999 * * * ]

procedure call

Note 2 to entry: procedure-call statement; procedure call: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-15:1999].

combination of language constructs from a programming language with those of natural language that is not necessarily computer-processible, but intended to make the design of a program manifest to human readers

2125566
pushdown storage
stack storage
stack
storage device in which data are ordered in such a way that the next data element to be retrieved is the most recently stored
Note 1 to entry: This method is characterized as "last in, first out" (LIFO).
Note 2 to entry: pushdown storage; stack storage; stack: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].
Note 3 to entry: 12.02.24 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2126101

inactive window

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-13 * 1996 * * * ]
2125567
pushup storage
storage device in which data are ordered in such a way that the next data element to be retrieved is the one stored first
Note 1 to entry: This method is characterized as "first in, first out" (FIFO).
Note 2 to entry: pushup storage: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].
Note 3 to entry: 12.02.25 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2125989
quadtree
expression of a two-dimensional object as a tree structure of quadrants, which are formed by recursively subdividing each nonhomogeneous quadrant until all quadrants are homogeneous with respect to a selected characteristic, or until a predetermined cutoff depth is reached
Note 1 to entry: The quadtree technique compresses the amount of stored data about a two-dimensional object.
Note 2 to entry: quadtree: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-13:1996].
Note 3 to entry: 13.02.36 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-13 * 1996 * * * ]
2122697
quality assurance
planned systematic activities necessary to ensure that a component or system conforms to established technical requirements
Note 1 to entry: quality assurance; QA: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-20:1990].
Note 2 to entry: 20.05.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-20 * 1990 * * * ]
2124133
quantize
divide the range of a variable into a finite number of non-overlapping intervals that are not necessarily of equal width, and to designate each interval by an assigned value within the interval
Note 1 to entry: Example: A person's age is for many purposes quantized with a quantum (interval) of 1 year.
Note 2 to entry: quantize: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 3 to entry: 02.09.11 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2122565
quarter-squares multiplier
analog multiplier whose operation is based on the identity xy = [(x+y)² - (x-y)²]/4, incorporating inverters, summers, and square-law function generators
Note 1 to entry: quarter-squares multiplier: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-19:1989].
Note 2 to entry: 19.01.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-19 * 1989 * * * ]
2121514
query
request to extract data directly or to derive them from a database, based on specified conditions
Note 1 to entry: Example: A request to a reservation system for availability of a seat on a specific flight.
Note 2 to entry: query: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-17:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 17.07.08 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-17 * 1999 * * * ]
2121513
query language
data manipulation language for users to retrieve and possibly modify data in a database
Note 1 to entry: Example: SQL.

Note 3 to entry: 17.07.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-17 * 1999 * * * ]
2121618
queue
pushup list
list that is constructed and maintained so that the next item to be retrieved is the one inserted earliest
Note 1 to entry: This method is characterized as "first-in-first-out" (FIFO).
Note 2 to entry: queue; pushup list: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-4:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 04.08.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-4 * 1999 * * * ]
2120684
radial basis function
activation function that is centered at a point specified by the connection weight vector and whose position and width are adjusted by learning
Note 1 to entry: In a radial basis function network, the radial basis functions are the activation functions of the hidden neurons, and constitute a basis set to represent the patterns.
Note 2 to entry: A radial basis function has a maximum or a minimum, in contrast with the usual activation functions that are monotonic. The most used radial basis function is the Gaussian function.
Note 3 to entry: radial basis function; RBF: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-34:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 34.03.14 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-34 * 1999 * * * ]
2120658
radial basis function network
RBF network
feedforward network in which each hidden neuron uses a radial basis function as the activation function and the output neurons implement linear combinations of these radial basis functions
Note 1 to entry: radial basis function network; RBF network: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-34:1999].
Note 2 to entry: 34.02.29 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-34 * 1999 * * * ]
2121067
radix
base
in radix notation, positive integer by which the weight of a given digit place is multiplied to obtain the weight of the digit place with the next higher weight
Note 1 to entry: Example: In the decimal system, the radix of each digit place is 10 and the weight at each digit place is an integral power of ten.
Note 2 to entry: In English, the term "base" is deprecated in this sense because of its mathematical use (see base (05.03.01)).
Note 3 to entry: radix; base: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 05.04.10 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2121098
radix complement
in fixed radix notation, complement that can be derived from a given number by subtracting it from a specified power of the radix
Note 1 to entry: Example: In the decimal system using three digits, 830 is the radix complement of 170, the power of the radix being 1 000 (=10³).
Note 2 to entry: The radix complement may be obtained by first deriving the diminished radix complement, then adding one to the least significant digit of the result and executing any carries required.
Note 3 to entry: radix complement: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 05.08.02 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2121066
radix notation
positional notation in which the ratio of the weight of any one digit place to the weight of the digit place with the next lower weight is a positive integer
Note 1 to entry: The permissible values of the digit in any digit place range from zero to the radix minus one of the digit place.
Note 2 to entry: radix notation: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 05.04.09 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]
2121068
radix point
in a representation of a number expressed in radix notation, location of the separation of the digits associated with the integral part from those associated with the fractional part
Note 1 to entry: radix point: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-5:1999].
Note 2 to entry: 05.04.11 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-5 * 1999 * * * ]

2123064
real open system
real system that complies with the requirements of open systems interconnection standards in its communication with other real systems
Note 1 to entry: This term is further described in ISO 7498.
Note 2 to entry: real open system: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-26:1993].
Note 3 to entry: 26.01.02 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-26 * 1993 * * * ]
2122925
real storage
main storage in a virtual storage system
Note 1 to entry: Physically, real storage and main storage are identical. Conceptually, however, real storage represents only part of the range of addresses available to the user of a virtual storage system. Traditionally, the total range of addresses available to the user was provided by the main storage.
Note 2 to entry: real storage: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-10:1979].
Note 3 to entry: 10.05.13 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-10 * 1979 * * * ]
2123063
real system
set of one or more computers, associated software, peripheral equipment, terminals, human operators, physical processes, and means of communication that form an autonomous whole capable of performing information processing or information transfer or both
Note 1 to entry: This term is further described in ISO 7498.
Note 2 to entry: real system: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-26:1993].
Note 3 to entry: 26.01.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-26 * 1993 * * * ]
2122900
real time
pertaining to the processing of data by a computer in connection with another process outside the computer according to time requirements imposed by the outside process
Note 1 to entry: The term "real time" is also used to describe systems operating in conversational mode and processes that can be influenced by human intervention while they are in progress.
Note 2 to entry: real time: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-10:1979].
Note 3 to entry: 10.03.04 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-10 * 1979 * * * ]
2122381
real type
data type, each data object of which represents a real number, possibly by approximation
Note 1 to entry: Example: The decimal number 0.1 in the binary system has an infinite number of digits.
Note 2 to entry: Real types are either fixed-point types or floating-point types.
Note 3 to entry: real type: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-15:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 15.04.08 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-15 * 1999 * * * ]

Note 2 to entry: recognition vocabulary; passive vocabulary: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-29:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 29.02.27 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-29 * 1999 * * * ]
2123053
reconfiguration
<reliability, maintainability, and availability> modification of the configuration of a functional unit following the detection of a fault or an error for the purpose of preventing a failure or bringing that functional unit back to a state in which it can perform a required function
Note 1 to entry: reconfiguration: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].

2122393
record type
composite type whose components are field types or other record types
Note 1 to entry: Example: A personnel record may consist of personal data arranged as fields or subrecords within this personnel record.
Note 2 to entry: A record type defines a set of values and operations. An instance of such a record type may contain values which themselves are records.
Note 3 to entry: This definition is identical to the definition in entry 17.05.13 of ISO/IEC 2382-17. The example and notes have been added.
Note 4 to entry: record type: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-15:1999].
Note 5 to entry: 15.04.20 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-15 * 1999 * * * ]

2122549
recovery time
when sending or receiving pulses, time required between the end of a pulse and the beginning of the next pulse
Note 1 to entry: The term usually applies to the equipment that sends or receives pulses.
Note 2 to entry: recovery time: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-21:1985].
Note 3 to entry: 21.04.05 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-21 * 1985 * * * ]
2120655
recurrent network
neural network in which the connections between artificial neurons form at least one feedback loop
Note 1 to entry: Examples: Hopfield network, Boltzmann machine.
Note 2 to entry: A nonlayered network is a recurrent network. A layered network is recurrent if there are connections between neurons within a given layer or connections from a given neuron to a neuron in a layer back toward the input.
Note 3 to entry: recurrent network: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-34:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 34.02.26 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-34 * 1999 * * * ]
2121841
recursion
process in which a subprogram either contains a subprogram call on itself, or calls another subprogram that calls the original subprogram or that initiates a further chain of subprogram calls that eventually leads back to a subprogram call of the original subprogram
Note 1 to entry: recursion: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].
Note 2 to entry: 07.03.16 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]
2124070
recursively defined sequence
sequence of terms in which each term after the first is determined by an operation in which the operands include some or all of the preceding terms
Note 1 to entry: In a recursively defined sequence, there may exist a finite number of non-defined terms, possibly greater than one.
Note 2 to entry: recursively defined sequence: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 3 to entry: 02.04.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2121163
redirection
transmittal event in which a message transfer agent replaces a user or distribution list among a message's immediate recipients with an alternate recipient
Note 1 to entry: redirection: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-32:1999].
Note 2 to entry: 32.04.24 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-32 * 1999 * * * ]
2123033
redundancy
<reliability, maintainability, and availability> existence of a means in addition to the means which would be sufficient for a functional unit to perform a required function or for data to represent information
Note 1 to entry: Examples - The use of duplicate functional components, the addition of parity bits.
Note 2 to entry: Redundancy is used primarily to improve reliability or availability.
Note 3 to entry: The definition in IEV 191-15-01 is less complete.
Note 4 to entry: redundancy: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].
Note 5 to entry: 14.01.12 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-14 * 1997 * * * ]
2123215
redundancy
<information theory> amount R by which the decision content H[subscript 0] exceeds the entropy H; in mathematical notation: R = H[subscript 0] - H
Note 1 to entry: Usually, messages can be represented with fewer characters by using suitable codes; the redundancy may be considered as a measure of the decrease of the average length of the messages accomplished by appropriate coding.
Note 2 to entry: Example: Let {a,b,c} be a set of three events and let p(a) = 0,5, p(b) = 0,25, and p(c) = 0,25 be the probabilities of their occurrences. The redundancy of this set is R = 1,58 Sh - 1,50 Sh = 0,08 Sh
Note 3 to entry: redundancy: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-16:1996].
Note 4 to entry: 16.03.05 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-16 * 1996 * * * ]
2124392
redundant code
code according to which more characters, symbols, or signal elements than strictly necessary are used to represent data
Note 1 to entry: redundant code: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-9:1995].
Note 2 to entry: 09.05.06 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-9 * 1995 * * * ]
2125538
reel
cylinder with flanges on which tape may be wound
Note 1 to entry: reel: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].
Note 2 to entry: 12.01.61 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2121845
reentrant
pertaining to a program or a part of a program in its executable version, that may be entered repeatedly, or may be entered before previous executions have been completed, and each execution of such a program is independent of all other executions
Note 1 to entry: reentrant: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].
Note 2 to entry: 07.03.20 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]

2121478
referential integrity
property of a set of relations such that the attribute values of foreign keys are null values or are identical to the values of primary keys of other relations

2121222
referral
suggestion to use an alternative access point, or directory system agent, given by a directory system agent to a directory user agent or another directory system agent, in case that a request to the directory system could not be resolved
Note 1 to entry: The reason for a referral may be that the information affected by the request is logically too far away.
Note 2 to entry: referral: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-32:1999].

Note 2 to entry: 13.03.14 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-13 * 1996 * * * ]
2120571
regular network
network in which each node or each class of nodes is connected to the same amount of branches
Note 1 to entry: Examples: Ring network, star network, grid network.
Note 2 to entry: A class of nodes is characterized by the relative position of the node within the networks, such as end nodes and intermediate nodes.
Note 3 to entry: regular network: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-18:1999].
Note 4 to entry: 18.03.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-18 * 1999 * * * ]

2121466
relation
set of entity occurrences that have the same attributes, together with these attributes
Note 1 to entry: In a relational database, a relation can be represented by a table with the rows corresponding to the entity occurrences and the columns corresponding to the attributes.
Note 2 to entry: relation: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-17:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 17.04.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-17 * 1999 * * * ]

all relations having identical sets of attributes
Note 1 to entry: A relation class can be characterized by a set of names of attributes.

Note 3 to entry: 17.04.02 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-17 * 1999 * * * ]
2121473
relational algebra
algebra for expressing and manipulating relations
Note 1 to entry: Common operations in a relational algebra are projection, selection, join, Cartesian product, disjunction, conjunction, and difference.

2125960
relative coordinate
any one of the coordinates identifying the position of an addressable point with respect to another addressable point
Note 1 to entry: relative coordinate: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-13:1996].
Note 2 to entry: 13.02.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-13 * 1996 * * * ]
2123214
relative entropy
ratio H[subscript r] of the entropy H to the decision content H[subscript 0]; in mathematical notation: H[subscript r] = H/H[subscript 0]
Note 1 to entry: Example: Let {a,b,c} be a set of three events and let p(a) = 0,5, p(b) = 0,25, and p(c) = 0,25 be the probabilities of their occurrences. The relative entropy of this set is H[subscript r] = 1,5 Sh / 1,580 Sh = 0,95
Note 2 to entry: relative entropy: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-16:1996].
Note 3 to entry: 16.03.04 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-16 * 1996 * * * ]
2124101
relative error
ratio of an absolute error to the true, specified or theoretically correct value of the quantity that is in error
Note 1 to entry: relative error: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 2 to entry: 02.06.09 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2123216
relative redundancy
ratio r of the redundancy R to the decision content H[subscript 0]; in mathematical notation: r = R/H[subscript 0]
Note 1 to entry: The relative redundancy is also equal to the complement to one of the relative entropy H[subscript r]: r = 1 - H[subscript r]
Note 2 to entry: relative redundancy: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-16:1996].
Note 3 to entry: 16.04.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-16 * 1996 * * * ]
2126013
relative vector
vector whose end point is specified as a displacement from its start point
Note 1 to entry: relative vector: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-13:1996].
Note 2 to entry: 13.03.22 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-13 * 1996 * * * ]
2123070
relay
set of functions, such as routing, enabling data received from one open system to be forwarded to another open system
Note 1 to entry: relay: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-26:1993].
Note 2 to entry: 26.01.08 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-26 * 1993 * * * ]
2123024
reliability
ability of a functional unit to perform a required function under given conditions for a given time interval
Note 1 to entry: The term used in IEV 191-02-06 is "reliability performance" and the definition is the same with additional notes.
Note 2 to entry: reliability: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].
Note 3 to entry: 14.01.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-14 * 1997 * * * ]
2123115
reliable transfer service element
application service element that guarantees the integrity of protocol data units exchanged between pairs of application entities involved in a given association, and provides for recovery from communication and end open system failures with a minimum number of retransmissions
Note 1 to entry: reliable transfer service element; RTSE: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-26:1993].
Note 2 to entry: 26.05.06 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-26 * 1993 * * * ]
2121940
relocatable
pertaining to all or part of an object program that can be loaded into any part of main storage
Note 1 to entry: The starting address is established by the loader, which then adjusts the addresses to reflect the storage locations into which program parts have been loaded.
Note 2 to entry: relocatable: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].
Note 3 to entry: 07.05.14 (2382)

2122088

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]
2121939

2121938
relocate
move all or part of an object program in an address space and make the necessary adjustment of addresses so that the corresponding program parts, resulting from this transformation, can be executed in the new location
Note 1 to entry: relocate: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].

2123043
remote maintenance
telemaintenance
online maintenance
maintenance of a functional unit provided through telecommunications with the assistance of, or under the control of, a maintenance facility at a remote location
Note 1 to entry: In this context, telecommunications does not include communication within a local area network on the premises of the functional unit.
Note 2 to entry: The definition in IEV 191-07-14 refers to maintenance being performed without physical access of the personnel to the item.
Note 3 to entry: remote maintenance; telemaintenance; online maintenance: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-14:1997].

2122485

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-15 * 1999 * * * ]
2121543
reorganization
change of the storage organization of a database according to its actual data structures or with the aim of a better fitting of its actual data structures, including the accommodation of the data already existing in the database in correspondence to the new organization
Note 1 to entry: Reorganization may be done to make the use of a storage device more efficient or to speed up the data access.
Note 2 to entry: reorganization: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-17:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 17.08.20 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-17 * 1999 * * * ]
2123238
repeater
In a local area network, device that amplifies and regenerates signals to extend the range of transmission between data stations or to interconnect two branches
Note 1 to entry: repeater: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-25:1992].
Note 2 to entry: 25.01.10 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-25 * 1992 * * * ]
2122070
repetitive addressing
method of implicit addressing in which the operation of an instruction is understood to address the operands of the last instruction executed
Note 1 to entry: repetitive addressing: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].
Note 2 to entry: 07.09.20 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]
2122586
repetitive operation
automatic repetition of the solution of a set of equations with fixed combinations of initial conditions and other parameters
Note 1 to entry: Repetitive operation is often used to permit the display of an apparently steady solution; it is also used to permit manual adjustment or optimization of one or more parameters.
Note 2 to entry: repetitive operation: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-19:1989].
Note 3 to entry: 19.02.08 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-19 * 1989 * * * ]
2126174
replace

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-23 * 1994 * * * ]
2122020
replay
technique in which the input data are captured and can be reintroduced into a program in such a manner as to cause execution of the program under controlled conditions for analysis
Note 1 to entry: replay: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-7:2000].
Note 2 to entry: 07.07.13 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]
2121183

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-32 * 1999 * * * ]
2121139
report
<electronic mail> information object that is generated by the message transfer system and that indicates the outcome or progress of a message's or probe's transmittal
Note 1 to entry: A report may indicate delivery or nondelivery of a message or of a probe.
Note 2 to entry: report: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-32:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 32.03.10 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-32 * 1999 * * * ]
2126394
repudiation
denial by one of the entities involved in a communication of having participated in all or part of the communication
Note 1 to entry: In the description of techniques and mechanisms the term "non-repudiation" is often used to mean that none of the entities involved in a communication can deny its participation in the communication.
Note 2 to entry: repudiation: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-8:1998].
Note 3 to entry: 08.06.25 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-8 * 1998 * * * ]

functional unit whose input analog variables are the polar coordinates of a point and whose output analog variables are the cartesian coordinates of the same point, or vice-versa
Note 1 to entry: A resolver can be qualified as PR (Polar - Rectangular/ Cartesian) or RP (Rectangular/Cartesian - Polar).

resource
computer resource
any element of a data processing system needed to perform required operations
Note 1 to entry: Example: Storage devices, input-output units, one or more processing units, data, files, and programs.

2123288
ring latency
in a ring network, time required for a signal to propagate once around the ring
Note 1 to entry: The ring latency includes the signal propagation delay through the ring medium, including drop cables, plus the sum of propagation delays through each data station connected to the token-ring network and is related to the data transmission rate.
Note 2 to entry: ring latency: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-25:1992].
Note 3 to entry: 25.04.03 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-25 * 1992 * * * ]
2120565
ring network
ring
network in which every node is an intermediate node with exactly two branches connected to it

Note 2 to entry: 18.03.01 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-18 * 1999 * * * ]
2122540
rise time
in the approximation of a step function, time required for a signal to change from a specified low value to a specified high value
Note 1 to entry: Usually these values are 10 % and 90 % of the step height.
Note 2 to entry: rise time: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-21:1985].

2121886
root compiler
compiler that compiles into an intermediate language only
Note 1 to entry: A root compiler, when combined with a code generator, comprises a full compiler.

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-7 * 2000 * * * ]

rotation
<computer graphics> revision of display elements so as to represent the turning of an object about a fixed axis

[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-13 * 1996 * * * ]
2125577
rotational position sensing
technique for continuously monitoring a disk position to indicate the position currently available for reading and writing
Note 1 to entry: This technique uses continuous comparison of the read/write head position with appropriate synchronization signals.
Note 2 to entry: rotational position sensing; RPS: term, abbreviation and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-12:1988].
Note 3 to entry: 12.02.35 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-12 * 1988 * * * ]
2122997
rote learning
learning strategy that consists in directly accumulating new knowledge without any inference being performed on the information provided
Note 1 to entry: Rote learning includes learning by direct memorization of given concept descriptions and learning by being programmed.
Note 2 to entry: rote learning: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-31:1997].
Note 3 to entry: 31.03.02 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-31 * 1997 * * * ]
2124126
round
delete or omit one or more of the least significant digits in a positional representation and to adjust the part retained in accordance with some specified rule
Note 1 to entry: The purpose of rounding is usually to limit the precision of the numeral or to reduce the number of characters in the numeral, or to do both these things.
Note 2 to entry: The most common arithmetic forms of rounding are rounding down, rounding up and rounding off.
Note 3 to entry: round: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 4 to entry: 02.09.04 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2124127
round down
round, making no adjustment to the part of the numeral that is retained.
Note 1 to entry: Example: The numerals 12.6374 and 15.0625, when rounded down to two decimal places, become 12.63 and 15.06 respectively.
Note 2 to entry: If a numeral is rounded down, its absolute value is not increased.
Note 3 to entry: Rounding down is a form of truncation.
Note 4 to entry: round down: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 5 to entry: 02.09.05 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2122855
round down function
function that allows the elimination in the result of the calculation of all digits beyond the least significant digit
Note 1 to entry: round down function: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-22:1986].
Note 2 to entry: 22.03.34 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-22 * 1986 * * * ]
2124129
round off
round, adjusting the part of the numeral retained by adding 1 to the least significant of its digits and executing any necessary carries, if and only if the most significant of the digits deleted was equal to or greater than half the radix of its digit place
Note 1 to entry: Example: The numerals 12.6375 and 15.0625, when rounded off to two decimal places, become 12.64 and 15.06, respectively.
Note 2 to entry: round off: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 3 to entry: 02.09.07 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2124130
round off
round, adjusting the part of the numeral retained by adding one to the least significant of its digits and executing any necessary carries, if: a) the most significant of the digits deleted was greater than half the radix of that digit place; b) the most significant of the digits deleted was equal to half the radix and one or more of the following digits were greater than zero; c) the most significant of the digits deleted was equal to half the radix, all the following digits were equal to zero, and the least significant of the digits retained was odd
Note 1 to entry: Example: The numerals 12.6375 and 15.0625, when rounded off to three decimal places, become 12.638 and 15.062, respectively.
Note 2 to entry: In this definition, even may be substituted for odd.
Note 3 to entry: round off: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 4 to entry: 02.09.08 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2124128
round up
round, adjusting the part of the numeral that is retained by adding 1 to the least significant of its digits and executing any necessary carries, if and only if one or more non-zero digits have been deleted
Note 1 to entry: Example: The numerals 12.6374 and 15.0625, when rounded up to two decimal places, become 12.64 and 15.07, respectively.
Note 2 to entry: If a numeral is rounded up, its absolute value is not decreased.
Note 3 to entry: round up: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 4 to entry: 02.09.06 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2122854
round-off function
function that allows the adding of one to the least significant digit in the result of a calculation together with the necessary carries, where the subsequent digit in the result is 5 or above; where the subsequent digit is 4 or below, the least significant digit remains unchanged
Note 1 to entry: round-off function: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-22:1986].
Note 2 to entry: 22.03.33 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-22 * 1986 * * * ]
2123270
round-trip propagation time
twice the time required for a bit to travel between the two most distant data stations in a bus network
Note 1 to entry: In a network using carrier sense, each frame must be long enough so that a collision or jam signal may be detected by the transmitting station while this frame is being transmitted. Its minimum length is therefore determined by the round-trip propagation time.
Note 2 to entry: round-trip propagation time: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-25:1992].
Note 3 to entry: 25.02.12 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-25 * 1992 * * * ]
2122853
round-up function
rounding
function that allows the adding of one to the least significant digit in the result of a calculation together with the necessary carries, if any of the highest decimal places dropped off has a value of more than zero
Note 1 to entry: round-up function; rounding: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-22:1986].
Note 2 to entry: 22.03.32 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-22 * 1986 * * * ]
2124108
rounding error
error due to rounding
Note 1 to entry: rounding error: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO 2382-2:1976].
Note 2 to entry: 02.06.16 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-2382-2 * 1976 * * * ]
2120554
router
functional unit that establishes a path through one or more computer networks
Note 1 to entry: In computer networks conforming to the OSI model, a router operates at the network layer.
Note 2 to entry: router: term and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-18:1999].
Note 3 to entry: 18.02.11 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-18 * 1999 * * * ]
2121375
routine
program
program, or part of a program, that may have some general or frequent use
Note 1 to entry: routine; program: terms and definition standardized by ISO/IEC [ISO/IEC 2382-1:1993].
Note 2 to entry: 01.05.04 (2382)
[SOURCE:ISO-IEC-2382-1 * 1993 * * * ]
2125498
